headline: GE Vernova Stock Recovers as the AI Trade Rebounds
summary: GE Vernova  was making a comeback Thursday, after a very bad day the previous session.  The drop appeared to be catalyzed by artificial-intelligence chip start-up Mythic, which recently raised $125 million to take on  Nvidia  The start-up is trying to design AI chips that solve “the biggest problem of AI—its insatiable, ruinous energy consumption,” according to Mythic.  In theory, lower energy consumption means less electricity needed and fewer AI business opportunities for GE Vernova.

headline: Here Are Thursday’s Top Wall Street Analyst Research Calls: Digital Realty, GE Vernova, Micron Technology, Merck & Co., Rivian, United Airlines, and More
summary: Pre-Market Stock Futures: Futures are trading higher on Thursday as we grind closer to the Christmas holiday, which is just a week off now. The song remains the same for the AI/Datacenter trade, and participants are finding it’s going to be a bit tougher here at the end of the year than in the last ... headline: This power infrastructure stock is a buy opportunity after pullback, analyst says
summary: Investing.com -- Shares in gas turbine maker GE Vernova (NYSE:GEV) have pulled back following the company’s December analyst day, creating what one analyst views as an attractive entry point as long-term fundamentals continue to strengthen.

headline: Stocks Climb Before the Open on Micron Boost Ahead of U.S. Inflation Data
summary: December S&P 500 E-Mini futures (ESZ25) are up +0.46%, and December Nasdaq 100 E-Mini futures (NQZ25) are up +0.74% this morning as forecast-beating quarterly results and guidance from Micron boosted sentiment.

headline: US Stock Market Today: S&P 500 Futures Rise as Traders Await Inflation Data
summary: The Morning Bull - US Market Morning Update Thursday, Dec, 18 2025 US stock futures are pointing higher this morning, with contracts linked to major indexes up around 0.3 to 0.7 percent as investors brace for fresh US inflation numbers. November consumer prices are expected to be about 3.1 percent higher than a year ago, which means the cost of living is still easing but not back to the Federal Reserve’s 2 percent comfort zone. At the same time, the 10 year US government bond yield is...
